Title: The Dark Tide
Author: Alicia Jasinska
My Review:
This book has an amazing, dark premise - it's plotted like a fairytale, and the plot isn't too stereotypical. It's deliberately a twist on the normal tale, and I was very excited for this going in. It was written well, from two separate perspectives, albeit with probably a little too much description of people's appearances for my liking. I loved the character of Eva, whose voice was unique and interesting - the scorned, lonely Witch Queen with complicated, swirling emotions and a distate for people being stupidly heroic. I didn't like the other main character, Lina, as much, but I could see that she was written well - the classic, annoyingly-brave main character who keeps the plot going.

I'm not going to lie, I wanted this book to be gayer than it was. I was enchanted by the idea of a sapphic version of this kind of fairytale, and the focus on the heterosexual relationship kind of detracted from its potential in my mind - but I can also see what Jasinska was trying to do.

Overall, the plot was well done, and the stakes were clear most of the time. There was something about Jasinska's writing style which made everything a bit of a blur, but it was very unique and I enjoyed reading her writing, even if sometimes I missed a crucial point and had to go back. The characters were well done, but I just wanted to hear more of Eva's story.

I commend this book for its fantastic concept and ideas - I didn't necessarily completely love the execution of those ideas, but I liked it nonetheless and I'm very excited to see more from this author.

Title: The Horse and His Boy (Chronicles of Narnia, #5)
Author: C.S. Lewis
My Review:
3.5 stars! I'm enjoying reading the Narnia books by audiobook with the BBC Full Cast Dramatization, but this one struck me as a bit weird? It's probably because the plot seems irrelevant to the main plot about Lucy, Edmund, Susan and Peter. I liked the characters, and they were relatively compelling (especially the horses!) but I didn't like how the story treated Aravis. I also felt simultaneously intrigued and slightly uncomfortable with how the story created parallels to Mohammed with Tisroc using the "may he live forever" suffix. It felt constantly like something biblical or religious was going on, but I don't know enough about biblical times to know what references were being made. I suspect that my BBC Audiobook version was deliberately edited to be more generic about these kinds of things.

The plot was quite generic, though still entertaining in the same way any classic fantasy might be. I probably enjoyed grown-up Susan and Edmund the best out of all the characters. Overall, I wasn't impressed by this book necessarily, but I'm glad I've read it as part of my exploration of the world of Narnia.

Title: To Night Owl, From Dogfish
Author: Holly Goldberg Sloan
My Review:
This middle-grade book is just so extraordinarily DIFFERENT. It's told entirely in emails, letters and other written forms of communication, between two girls whose dads have recently become a couple. Their feelings towards each other change over the course of the book, but they are complicated and real and I love it.

To Night Owl From Dogfish is about family - found family, new family, and blended family. It's about accepting people for who they are, at all ages. It's about genuinely-written twelve year olds and what it's like to be a kid in a world of adult problems. It's about love and divorce, and how families can change so quickly and children's worlds can be changed all so suddenly and all at once.

I loved the way the unique storytelling method added complexity to each character, and the way the most dramatic moments in the story were told in retrospect in a series of emails, but somehow it all made it so much more dramatic. This novel was never boring, even though substantial sections just involved the ordinary everyday conversation between two twelve-year-olds. So many parts were hilarious and witty, and I just loved reading it and delving into their world. All the while, you can see the Big Plot forming in the background, and you know it's going to be interesting.

It's a middle grade book, but also very well worth reading for people all of all ages!

Some of my favourite quotes include:
"...families are made from people who want to be together more than they want to be apart."
"Someday EVEN THIS will be a good memory."

Title: All This Time
Author: Mikki Daughtry
Publisher: Simon  Schuster Books for Young Readers
My Review:
3.5 stars! This was the kind of book I probably would have loved more if I was younger and also from a different demographic. I didn't realise this at first, but it started as a screenplay written by Mikki Daughtry, and was adapted into a novel by Rachael Lippincott.

All This Time is an adorable, fluffy romcom that believes in true love and is full of all of your favourite guilty-pleasure tropes, while simultaneously executing a classic "unbelievable" plot idea. It's going to sound similar to all of your favourite rom-com movies, but in a way that's okay - it's just different enough to keep you guessing, and keep you caring.

I started out the book extremely cynical of the main character, a quarterback in love with the cheerleader, who spends the first half of the book being obsessive and essentially moping around. But then in the second half, everything was turned on its head and the main character started growing up and learning what was important. There was strong character development, and yet my feminism senses remained a little uncomfortable with the way the character of Marley was portrayed.

This book surprised me, in a good way. It's a very good book - I just worry that I might have stopped reading early in the first half if I wasn't invested in reading it as a NetGalley book, and for me this is its main downfall. The characters, without the plot from the second half of the book, just weren't compelling enough to draw me in. Maybe I don't see enough of myself in them, because they're the "popular kids". It doesn't take away from the brilliantly executed plot, and the well-designed, subtle morals of the story, but the characters just didn't click with me.

Thankfully, I know they will definitely click with someone else. The authors have put a little gem out into the world which will resonate with many people.

Grateful to NetGalley and Simon & Schuster for giving me an advanced reader's copy of this book in exchange for an honest review!

Title: The Yield: A Novel
Author: Tara June Winch
My Review:
"Before colonisation there were two hundred and fifty distinct languages in Australia that subdivided into six hundred dialects. ... In the last two hundred years, Australia has suffered the largest and most rapid loss of languages known to history. Today, despite efforts of revitalisation, Australia's languages are some of the most endangered in the world."

This book is framed as a dictionary of words from the language of the Wiradjuri people, recorded by Albert Gondiwindi in the years just prior to his passing. It is interspersed with a narrative about Albert's granddaughter, August Gondiwindi, who still grapples with the loss of her parents and her sister. Interestingly, it is supplemented by diary entries from the perspective of the German Reverend who helped run the original Aboriginal mission on the site where the Gondiwindis' house now stands - and where it is about to be demolished by a big mining company.

I really enjoyed listening to this book as an audiobook, partly because the narrator's voice was so calm and knowledgeable, and authentic. I'm not sure I would have enjoyed it as much if I had just read it on paper (though by the same token, I felt compelled to get a copy of the eBook so that then I could look at all the Wiradjuri words in the dictionary and write them down). However, I also enjoyed this story much more than I would any ordinary "Australian historical fiction" (which I normally find boring and unnecessarily descriptive, with a tendency towards caricatures rather than characters). To a large extent, I enjoyed this novel more because of the insight offered by the First Nations author into all of these well-worn plotlines. The dictionary framing was a work of genius, and the relationship between the multi-generational plotlines worked very well for this kind of universal story about finding home and finding justice.

Moreover, this book is important to read. It's important because it is a calm, measured, OwnVoices Aboriginal perspective on the over-criminalisation of First Nations people, the need for a treaty in Australia, the difficulties and politics of native title, the short-sightedness of political activists, and the connection with family, land and ancestors. Thank you to Tara June Winch for sharing this story, and for sharing this language. I will do all I can to remember and respect it.

Title: Hush (Hush, #1)
Author: Dylan Farrow
My Review:
Thank you to NetGalley and Wednesday Books / St Martin's Press for giving me an advanced reader's copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

This book is about a girl searching for the truth. It's about how a system ostensibly designed to protect can become corrupt. It's about a young person caught up in the lies of everyone around her, desperate to get out.

But for me, the problem was that I already knew exactly what the main character's revelations would be. I could predict what was going on with the plot, and who was taking advantage of whom. The big realisations at the end were far from groundbreaking, although various twists in the last 10% of the book made me want to pick up the sequel to find out what happens.

I also found it difficult to care about the main character, who seemed perpetually reckless and sure of herself, but always seemed to miraculously survive everything she was put through. I never felt like anything could break her down enough to stop her. Maybe it's because she began the book starting from nothing, or maybe because she seemed to accept the "chosen one" arc incredibly easily for someone who should already distrust the system.

Despite the brilliant ideas behind this book - words being the source of all magic, and also the source of the Plague - and the interesting plot arc it attempted, I wasn't convinced that Farrow's writing helped the story land in the way it could have. Mostly, I was disappointed to find that I was reading a predictable book full of cliches and deus ex machinas, and I didn't care about the character enough to invest in her future. Thanks to the last 10-20%, I'm still interested in the plot, but I hope that any sequels to this book will take this plot opportunity and flesh it out further in more interesting ways.

Title: The Song of Achilles
Author: Madeline Miller
My Review:
This book floored me. Miller writes with dizzyingly beautiful prose, pulling you in from the beginning with tales of Ancient Greek heroes - articulated like the book you're reading is from the legends themselves. It all feels extremely authentic. What's more, it's a heartwarming, tragic tale of queer love, told in a way that universally applies to anyone who has ever loved someone and missed them dearly.

It's a slow build, with just enough tension to keep you going through the beginning of the book, but also many scenes of just pure young passion - dreamy days out in the woods that you wish would go forever. It turns into politics, and it turns into war. It turns into prophecies, and gods, and epic battles, and tragedy. It turns the tide of the plot so slowly and so quickly all at once. It reminds you of the longest, most pointless wars, where nothing is achieved and the most important things fall by the wayside - shot down in a blaze of arrogant glory, men too proud to raise their shields to what they know is coming.

I also can't stress how much I love the characters in this book - each an independent character, a mythology of their own. Patroclus and Achilles get their story. Briseis gives us a beautiful arc for the plot to follow. By the end of the book, my eyes were glued to the page and all I could hear was the beating of my heart as I just. kept. reading.

Read this book - it's a modern classic for a reason.

Title: The Poppy War (The Poppy War, #1)
Author: R.F. Kuang
My Review:
I absolutely loved this book. It traces the story of Rin, a determined young woman willing to do anything to make a better life for herself. Kuang investigates Rin's character from all angles, pushing her to her limit in the way that characters should be pushed. The author throws curveballs at the plot frequently, intensely, but it's always well-executed and finely woven into the earlier parts of the novel. Even though it's a very long book, there's never a lull in the steady classic-fantasy build - from training, to war, to disaster.

I loved the morally-grey characters, the obsession with power and the frank, clever way the author approached fictional approximations of historical tragedies. I loved how real everything felt - how people changed sides, went crazy, lost everything, and perpetrated exceptional cruelties. This book is a very dark fantasy, and it's not your average epic - not only is it set in fictional Asia, it's fast-paced despite its length and subject matter. The main character is exceptionally brave, but very very flawed in more ways than you would ever expect of a fantasy female lead. She also doesn't immediately fall into a love triangle, or any relationship at all.

Thank you to my friends at the Life's Library Readathon for recommending this book to me! This is EXACTLY the kind of book I've been waiting for - the kind of book which is true to the fantasy tropes I love most but gives them some extremely clever, compelling twists in its execution. I would recommend it very highly to anyone who ever liked fantasy books - just be warned, it might knock your expectations out of the park and you might wind up with a new favourite...

Title: Each of Us a Desert
Author: Mark Oshiro
My Review:
This book is all at once unique and contemplative. It tracks the story of Xochitl, a cuentista who has the power and duty to absorb anyone's story in a process akin to Catholic confession and "give it back" to Solis, the sun god. It's set in either a dystopian future or a sci fi world, in which everything was destroyed by the sun and the world is a desert. It's written as one big story told to the sun god. It deals with people's "stories" and how they are told and kept safe. It's full of well-used "they/their" pronouns, and it treats queer relationships as normal and doesn't even question their queerness. On top of all this, the story is told about half in Spanish (which I don't understand), but once you got over the initial hurdle of understanding, they were integrated extremely well into the story and added to the authenticity of the world it was based in.

The plot was a very slow build, and I enjoyed it, but it wasn't all-consuming. I knew that each time I picked up the book, every bit I read would have some kind of slow character development at the very least. Xochitl was a good character, but not overly compelling. What compelled me the most about her character was her relationship with Emilia, which I absolutely loved. I also didn't see the very final resolution coming, but I was very happy with the way the author resolved the plot relating to all the stories coming alive and haunting the characters in the desert.

This book is very dark at times, and not a light read at all, but it's a book about freedom, love, religion and stories. It's about finding yourself and coming to peace with who you are and what your journey has been up until now. It is about the journey, not the destination. Oshiro executes their vision of this book very well. It's not for everyone, but many of the aspects should be highly commended. I hope this book becomes a classic in its genre.

Thank you to NetGalley and Tor Teen for providing me with a free advanced copy of this book in exchange for an honest review!

Title: The Dragon of Ynys
Author: Minerva Cerridwen
My Review:
This is a short, all-ages fairytale about an asexual, aromantic knight called Sir Violet whose job is to find and return items that the dragon nearby has taken from the little village of Ynys. But when one day the lesbian baker goes missing, what will Sir Violet do? He reminds me of Bilbo Baggins - after all, he goes on the whole adventure of this novel and all he wanted was some cinnamon rolls...

I felt a lot like Sir Violet reading this book. I knew from its blurb that it would be cute and adorable and easy to read, and full of fun medieval shenanigans, but I didn't expect that it would be full of so much heart.

Consider the story of a fairytale dragon: he's usually the only one of his kind, living a lonely existence up in the mountains. Others are scared of him and don't know how to interact with him.
The author makes the point that, in the real world, many LGBT+ people are treated like dragons and shunned from the village. But she makes it with nuance and vigour, centering queer voices in the story and giving them real depth. Characters pursue real friendships, navigate real (and complicated) relationships, and learn how to listen to each other's stories. And importantly, they don't just ride off into the sunset together at the end.

Here is one of my favourite quotes from the book:
"It was odd, really. They had all these tales about rare creatures like dragons ... yet he'd never heard a single one about a girl whose identity did not match the way her body was perceived by others."

Thank you to NetGalley and Atthis Arts for giving me an advanced copy of this book in exchange for an honest review! And thank you [a:Minerva Cerridwen|15904760|Minerva Cerridwen|https://images.gr-assets.com/authors/1590500035p2/15904760.jpg] for re-writing this book and putting it back out into the world - the world needs many many more adorable stories just like this.

Title: Shout
Author: Laurie Halse Anderson
My Review:
3.5 stars! This was a very high quality set of poems - I just didn't personally love it. It deals with many very important themes, and several of the poems hit the nail on the head with the way they describe their content. This is a book about sexual abuse, and survivors of this trauma. It is about how they go on.

The poems were well designed around common themes, and told the story of Anderson's life. They also told smaller stories, turning thoughts into poems that sat well together over the course of the book. They were so vivid that I almost felt compelled to hide them away.

The problem for me, I think, was that I struggled (as with Speak) to connect with the main character. It felt less like I was being invited into her world and more like I was being kept at arm's length. I understand why, but I would have preferred to be actively thrown into the character's entire world. Often, I felt like something was missing. Maybe that's just the detached nature of poetry, or the nature of the subject, but it caused me to disconnect from the writing. Maybe I just wasn't in the right headspace.

So I recommend reading this book of poetry slowly, and carefully. You never know when the next poem is going to hit you hard in the guts. I felt less like I was sharing something with the author and more like I was being told something, and occasionally it was something I didn't want to hear. Poetry should do this - poetry should challenge you, and hit you hard - but it's important to consider your limits when reading content like this. Check in with your head and your heart before you do.

Title: Ciel
Author: Sophie Labelle
My Review:
Thank you to NetGalley and Second Story Press for gifting me with this advanced copy in exchange for an honest review.

Going in, I was very excited to read a book about a non-binary character and their experience of the world. On that front, this book absolutely soared: I learnt about the intricacies of everything from navigating friendships to getting dressed, from being a queer YouTuber to being a kid just starting high school. I really appreciated seeing the world through Ciel's eyes, and from their perspective, with an honest style of narration.

However, there were a couple of major things that disappointed me about this book, and many of them may be personal. I felt jarred by the uncritical discussion of various teenage themes, and the way the author expected the reader to just accept that two characters this age were in committed, long-term relationships with boyfriends in early high school/ middle school. Although these characters were mainly developed in an age-appropriate way, this contributed to my unease. Yes, debateable things aren't meant to be critically analysed in middle-grade books, but should they be presented entirely uncritically? I'm concerned mostly because it might lead more conservative readers to think that, in turn, the narrator is just uncritically presenting other important viewpoints, when in fact Ciel makes various good arguments about the majority of the trans / gender-related issues.

I was also very underwhelmed by the lack of plot / plot resolution and the lack of substantial character development - very few of the things that happened caused any anguish in the protagonist, or for the protagonist to want something. I wanted to have a reason to be passionate about this character, but I struggled to find one.

All of these things might just be my personal inclination to have a strong plot / strong character development, rather than a slice of life, and my hesitation to invest in a story which (outside of the broad plot about Ciel being non-binary / trans) seemed to be more or less about social circles, boyfriends and complaining about a life which is ultimately pretty good. That being said, I think this book is VERY important for its incredible representation of trans issues and queer issues generally, and I commend the author for having the bravery to put this story out into the world. Thank you for sharing your experiences - even if I didn't connect with the characters, reading this book has taught me a lot.

Title: Red, White & Royal Blue
Author: Casey McQuiston
My Review:
This book came highly recommended and it met every single expectation I had of it. Want a subtle, empathetic insight into what it's like to be queer in politics? Gotcha. Want interesting, vulnerable, multi-layered protagonists? Boom. Multi-layered like a giant royal wedding cake. Want hilarious quips and comments littered in amongst touching love letters? You got 'em.

I listened to this book as an audiobook and even though I know I would still have loved it as a paperback, the audiobook added something more. I started the book thinking Alex was a complete jackass, but learned to love him as the pages wore on - his actions spoke louder than words. I started the book thinking Henry would be a paper-thin Handsome Prince - but boy, was I wrong. This isn't just a romance (though it's a beautiful, heartbreaking, funny, gut-wrenching love story) - it's the story of two intricately developed characters with their own lives, their own family problems. Their stories are intertwined, and the impact they have on each other's worlds just keeps endlessly driving the plot along. It's exactly what a compelling story ought to be.

This book was very steamy, and almost in danger of becoming "fan-fiction-y" and superficial, but the author turned down the steam when appropriate and filled out all the important parts of the book with love and commitment - raising the stakes exponentially with family love, sibling love, platonic love, and romantic love. Oh, and did I mention there's a non-romance plot, a complicated POLITICS plot, going on in the background? It adds so much depth to Alex, Henry, and all the characters around them. What's more, everything doesn't just magically resolve itself. There's still a future for these characters beyond the pages of this book.

I would 100% recommend this book to anyone - particularly if you are looking for a really good queer romance. You go through an emotional rollercoaster, but you won't be disappointed by how it all ends. These queer characters get a book for themselves - a book that isn't just about their queerness, or even about their love. It's about them, as people, and that's what makes it so fantastic.

Title: Ayesha at Last
Author: Uzma Jalaluddin
My Review:
I'm going to start this review by saying that I'm not a particularly big fan of, nor am I very familiar with, the plot of Pride and Prejudice. However, I have read the original Austen and I was captivated by the idea of a modern muslim retelling of the classic tale - and I wasn't disappointed.

It took me a long time to get into this book, but by the time I hit three-quarters of the way through I was falling fast into the action. I really admired the world-building and the fact that the author unashamedly used muslim and South Asian terms and references without much explanation. It helped me feel like I was properly immersed in this world and this culture, and this was definitely my favourite part about the book.

Similarly, I admired the way that Jalaluddin characterised her "Mr Darcy" character, Khalid. She went out on a limb for many (if not most) Western readers by characterising him as very conservative and more or less an Islamic fundamentalist. She confronted Islamophobia head-on, particularly by contrasting the "good" and "bad" muslim stereotypes between Ayesha and Khalid. I think the fact that this is a Pride and Prejudice retelling is the most critical part of the point she makes. We were all okay with Mr Darcy being a sexist prick in Pride and Prejudice - why shouldn't we be okay with a similar conservative male figure in a conservative society being a similarly sexist prick in this book? It makes the reader confront any perceived biases against muslim people - particularly muslim men - and I think that this is really special.

This book was recommended to me by my friends at the Life's Library Readathon group, particularly SaraCat, and I am very grateful that they convinced me to read it. I don't love this kind of romance myself, and I don't love Pride and Prejudice, but I think that the exploration of biases in this book is absolutely top-notch. I would recommend it to anyone, especially if they are the kind of person who would call themselves a progressive - precisely because it made me think twice about my own hidden assumptions and misgivings.

Author: Hank Green
My Review:
After my complicated feelings about An Absolutely Remarkable Thing (AART), this book was a pleasant surprise. I felt that it probably went on for a little bit too long than it needed to, and it was a little bit self-indulgent in the beginning, but once the book ramped up it got extremely interesting.

Unlike in AART, Hank used various POV characters to tell this book, which gave him a lot more room to manoeuvre, and made his characters significantly more likeable for me. They all still kind of sounded like Hank, but it was less blatantly annoying than when the only POV character was April. One or two of the POV characters really kept me reading, but I couldn't find it in myself to care as much about the others.

Hank's book is very quotable, very well-plotted, suprising and funny. I didn't love any of the characters, and I suspect that what I'll remember most is the plot. I appreciated the many sparks of brilliance in this book, and I really respected the execution of the project that was started in AART. Hank planned this duology very well, and he definitely got his point across. It was enjoyable to read, but I just didn't connect with the characters as much as I felt I could have.

Title: Persepolis 2: The Story of a Return (Persepolis, #2)
Author: Marjane Satrapi
My Review:
Note that this is my review for both Persepolis volumes (I and II).

I'm not a big reader of graphic novels but this is one that I really loved. It's an autobiographical retelling of Marjane Satrapi's childhood and coming of age, and it reads like any "normal" coming of age story, but there's one really big difference: she's growing up during the Iranian Revolution.

I really admire how deftly and honestly Satrapi tells her story, weaving bits of politics and history into a story which is ultimately about family and belonging, growing up and leaving the nest. This is a story that everyone can relate to, even though it deals explicitly and implicitly with so many different themes on so many subtle levels. I found myself constantly learning, constantly questioning my pre-conceptions about the Iranian revolution and Iranians in general. This book addresses the differences between fundamentalism and Islam itself, and the complexities of living in a war zone. It gives us the incredibly unique, well-articulated viewpoint of a child, teenager and young adult, coming to terms with what makes her different and what makes her special, in a world which is already so complicated. If anything can make you re-evaluate your own opinions about people from other cultures and backgrounds, this is the book.

I think it's incredibly important that this book is read by more people. It's accessible, easy to read, and only really took me a few hours' total reading time. It's well-illustrated, funny, and heartbreaking. I couldn't physically stop reading after the first volume, knowing there was a second volume. I put one down and picked the next one right up, I was so enthralled.

Marjane Satrapi - thank you for sharing your story with the world.

Title: The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo
Author: Taylor Jenkins Reid
My Review:
I read this as an audiobook and enjoyed every single second of it. All of the characters were built with such complexity and the dialogue was full of so much subtle insight that I found it actively difficult to stop listening. I'd highly recommend the audiobook in itself - with a wonderful cast of voice actors - but the plot, the characters and the pacing kept me going.

Evelyn is the kind of character you want to love and hate at the same time. You think you know exactly what crazy Hollywood drama she's going to get involved in next, and you think maybe it'll be shallow or over-the-top, but what you really get is something more subtle. You learn about the intricacies of Hollywood, through the sexism and the racism and the discrimination against LGBTQ+ people. You learn to empathise with the struggle of a very famous and powerful woman to learn how to value her family and her love at the cost of everything else. You watch generations pass as Evelyn goes from a young Cuban upstart to a glamorous aging movie star.

This book is about family. It's about not being afraid to love who you were made to love. It deals with sexuality, with sex, with marriage, with love and with friendship - all as completely different, separate things. It keeps you guessing about Evelyn's many husbands, but it all comes together just right in the end. You feel like you've become intensely familiar with this one woman and her impact on the world, her life and her fame - and its impact on her. You know everything about her family, and everything about what matters to her.

You don't need to love Hollywood and celebrity to love this book - you just need to be fascinated by people. This book is by turns exhilirating and heartbreaking, with a romance that tears at your heart and a lifelong friendship which is just as powerful. This book and its characters will stay close to my heart for a long time yet, and I'd recommend it to anyone.

Title: Fable (Fable, #1)
Author: Adrienne Young
My Review:
This book had everything you could ask for in a beautiful, magical, readable and compelling fantasy series. At the start, it was the great plot and the interesting main character and her quest to find the father who had abandoned her that grabbed me, and by the end I was fully invested in all the major characters and super excited to read the sequel. It left off on a small cliffhanger, but the reason I want to read the next book isn't about the cliffhanger - it's just about wanting to spend more time with this motley crew of characters.

Adrienne Young expresses the intricacies of this world so well, and uses it as a device to hold back character information in a way that serves both her plot needs and our enjoyment of the story itself. Every chapter ends in a little cliffhanger, keeping us going and keeping us hooked into the plot. Each chapter is short, and makes you want to gobble up just one more chapter of that beautiful story - just to find out what happens to your intrepid main character and cast. What's more, Young's prose is filled with vivid details, sprinkled through expertly without a trace of getting sidetracked from the action in each scene. It feels like you're looking at a scene from a painting which has come to life. It's this writing style which makes the seafaring setting really come to life. See below some quotes from Fable - examples of Young's beautiful writing.

Overall, I gave this book 4.5 stars because it was just a very good fantasy book at a very high standard. It didn't have anything particularly out-there, but it gets many points for just how compellingly it was written. There's an unexpected romance, structured to peak in an unconventional way, and tons of interesting dynamics between the main characters. I couldn't fault the writing, and the plot and characters were both very well done and executed. I've found myself thinking about these characters every day since I finished reading the book. I can't wait to read more!

I'm very grateful to both NetGalley and Wednesday Books / St Martin's Press for giving me a free copy of this eARC in exchange for an honest review.

Title: Speak: The Graphic Novel
Author: Laurie Halse Anderson
My Review:
This was an extremely well-done graphic novel. It deals with the incredibly important but incredibly difficult subject of rape, and the consequences as they manifest themselves in the life of a young woman in high school. I am particularly impressed with how well the graphic novel captures the feelings and experiences of the main character through a combination of dialogue (by the author) and beautiful illustration (by the artist). Many pages just made me stop and take a deep breath, or made me want to barrel on and keep reading to learn more about the main character and her story.

I didn't personally invest much in the main character, but I admired the way it was written. The author made it clear from the beginning that the main character had depression, and followed a predictable but still interesting arc about how she would work towards a life free from the pain of this traumatic event.

It was an enjoyable, short read (I read it in one evening) but at the same time I learnt a lot. I learnt a lot about the subtleties of life afterwards - after the abuse. I learnt a lot about what it means to be a "survivor". This is a story that everyone should read.

Title: An Absolutely Remarkable Thing (The Carls, #1)
Author: Hank Green
My Review:
3.5 stars!

I had some complicated feelings about this book. I've been a long-time nerdfighter, and I ordered the signed copy of this book all the way over in Australia because I wanted to support Hank Green as a creator. First of all, the concept blew me away: using the idea of an alien invasion / First Contact situation to talk about YouTube fame and stardom? Genius. Honestly, genius. Nobody's ever thought of that before - at least, I've never even heard of a book like that. It was well written, with a plot that was only slightly predictable, and the (very spoilerific) ending blew me away because I was definitely not expecting that to happen. I'm hooked, and I want to read the next one. I have to know how this finishes. It has a very compelling plot, one which is well-developed.

I also really liked the insights into fame that are peppered throughout the book. It really did feel like a memoir, and many of the plot choices made April a compelling character. But it also made her extremely hateable. I know this is fine, and that it's okay to still like books where the main character really frustrates you, but there was one extra element that frustrated me: She sounded just like Hank. She didn't sound like April May. I love the vlogbrothers, and I'm interested in what Hank has to say, but I'm not sure that I want to hear it through a caricature.

What I'm saying is that my existing knowledge of Hank Green as a person probably made this book less enjoyable for me, because it seemed like April May was just a self-insert for Hank. Sure, I learnt a lot of things about fame, but I would have more happily read an autobiography. I think this book will be fantastic for anyone who has never heard of Hank Green The Internet Personality, but I had. It was still a good book in many other ways - from side characters to plot development - but I just didn't enjoy it as much as I could have.

Title: Space Struck
Author: Paige Lewis
My Review:
This is a beautiful little anthology of poems I am reading with Life's Library this month, and I have been absolutely loving each of the poems. They're quiet and reflective, and not overstated. They aren't too fancy, and they aren't too confusing. I "got" something out of almost every poem, and even when I didn't get it, there were very few poems where I didn't just enjoy Lewis's thoughtful, articulate collection of words into poetry.

This poetry collection, and discussing each poem with the Life's Library book club, inspired me to create my own poetry. It made me want to share each poem with everyone around me. It made me want to read the poems out loud just to hear what they sounded like. Lewis's work deals with themes from relationships and anxiety to our place in the universe. It's the kind of book you can pick up over and over again, and I know that I absolutely will.

The poems that really stuck with me included:
- On The Train, A Man Snatches My Book
- Saccadic Masking
- When I Tell My Beloved I Miss The Sun
- When They Find The Ark
- My Dear Wolfish Dreamboat, Stand Still
- On Distance
- You Can Take Off Your Sweater, I've Made Today Warm
- The River Reflects Nothing
- Last Night I Dreamed I Made Myself
- God's Secretary, Overworked
- Magic Show
- So You Want To Leave Purgatory

It's quite a lot! Many of these poems are little jewels worth keeping safe and reading over and over again. If this many poems spoke to me, how many will speak to you?

Title: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe (Chronicles of Narnia, #1)
Author: C.S. Lewis
My Review:
3.5 stars!

I liked this book as a kid, but mostly because it was an adventure in an interesting world. Reading the audiobook back - the BBC Full Cast Dramatisation one - was fun, but I don't feel like I learnt anything new! The audioplay was really well done (more dialogue than anything else) but I found myself being more cynical this time about the built-in biblical references. It's a bit unsettling to think about how successful these narratives were when I was a kid, but I guess a lot of that comes from the fact that the story it's based on is one of the oldest, much loved stories of all time. It's very compelling. And CS Lewis weaves a believable, magical world for kids, despite my cynicism.

Title: The Death of Vivek Oji
Author: Akwaeke Emezi
My Review:
Reading this book was like watching a flower slowly open up and bloom. Each layer I peeled off the top gave me more insight into the mystery of what lay inside, but each layer was also beautiful in itself.

The book is about Vivek Oji, but it is also about the people around him, the people whose lives were intertwined with his. It tells a sensitive story that reads a little bit like an 1800s family drama, but seamlessly integrates elements of life in Nigeria. It sets up character perspectives that help you piece together the mystery but simultaneously make you want to know more about the character themselves.

One of the best ways I can describe this book is "brave". Akwaeke Emezi tackles difficult themes - themes of love, family, home, guilt, redemption, sex and what it means to be LGBTIQ+ in Nigeria. When you read the book, even if you think the plot is starting to look predictable, you may well be surprised about what you find. In the end, this book reminds the reader that sometimes being afraid, being too careful, or caring too much, might be what hurts you the most.

I was given an electronic advanced reader's copy of this book from NetGalley and Faber & Faber Ltd in exchange for an honest, unbiased review.

"If nobody sees you, are you still there?"

Title: With the Fire on High
Author: Elizabeth Acevedo
My Review:
This book is a Mighty-Ducks, Glee, classic-high-school-sports-drama-style plot, with characters who absolutely shine. The main character became a mother at 15 and is finishing her high school degree with dreams to become a chef but the reality of a two-year-old at her side. Acevedo's poetic prose (it's actually prose this time) tells the story of Emoni's senior year in little snippets and glimpses, a well-designed structure which adds spice to a largely linear plot. Thanks to Emoni's incredible cooking talents and Acevedo's wonderful writing, some chapters are full of descriptions which make your tummy rumble just reading them and other chapters are just straight-up recipes, adding an extra dimension to the book. I felt like I could just pick up Emoni's recipe and taste a part of the book itself.

Many side characters were interesting and well developed, especially her best friend Angelica and her grandmother 'Buela. This book was about family, and it was about motherhood, and it was about coping when the world throws everything at you in a blur. It felt like my own senior year with just the way it was told. There's so much going on in your final year of high school, and on top of all that you're just trying to work out what you want to do for the rest of your life. No big deal.

Emoni is a brilliant character because she's just like any other young woman finishing high school - she just has to deal with all the complications of having a child as well, and with knowing it'll be financially difficult (impossible, even) to follow her dream. This book is really well written and definitely worth reading - for the characters, for the representations, and for the themes they represent. There are lots of hard choices in this book, and Acevedo writes about them in a story simultaneously filled with all the light and fun of a classic YA novel. It really does feel like senior year all over again.

Title: Wolf-Speaker (Immortals, #2)
Author: Tamora Pierce
My Review:
I loved all of Tamora Pierce's works as a kid, and have read almost all of them except the new Numair books. But when I realised that the nerdfighter Tamora Pierce book club was reading through the entire series, I jumped at the chance to join. I decided to read the audiobook, however, to switch it up a little bit.

I don't remember liking this book quite as much as the other ones in the Immortals quartet as a kid, probably because I never really enjoyed books that were heavily about animals / animal magic and this one was entirely about Daine discovering her powers and her pack. But I think as an adult I liked it a lot more because I could really appreciate (as a creative writing student now) how well-designed and fleshed out Tamora Pierce's world is. I also laughed out loud many times at this book, and thanks to the slow burn of an audiobook I think I remembered all the minor characters much better.

I didn't love the audiobook itself (probably because I already had voices for all these characters in my head) and I wouldn't read this book again for no specific reason, but I'm glad that I did. It's really nice to revisit a world and the characters you loved as a kid. You look at them differently now, and it's a nice exercise in self-reflection to think about why exactly that might be so.

Title: The Black Kids
Author: Christina Hammonds Reed
Publisher: Simon  Schuster Books for Young Readers
My Review:
This book is everything I thought it would be, and more. It's an #ownvoices book by a strong Black woman about the coming-of-age story of a young, rich, Black girl living in LA during the Rodney King riots. I knew nothing about the riots before starting this book, and I've come away from it wanting to learn so much more.

The main character, Ashley - her identity seemingly a contradiction in terms - was extremely well developed by the author. Although at the beginning of the book she and her friends seemed to be one-dimensional "popular kids", Reed didn't shy away from introducing complicated situations to develop Ashley's character. There was nothing predictable about the way she tackled the subject of high school friendships crumbling, or the way she painted a picture of a complicated, raw, family struggle to belong. Even the romance in the book wasn't immediately predictable, which is really saying something for YA books. Better yet, Ashley found herself in a lot of moral grey areas, some of which I'm not even sure were resolved by the end of the book. It makes Ashley real and three-dimensional, and I loved reading more about her story.

Outside of that, Ashley is accompanied by a whole cast of characters you love to root for, and whose plotline is well developed: Lana, who gave me some serious Perks of Being a Wallflower vibes; Jo, the sister and perfect foil to the main character's experiences of prejudice; and Lucia, whose story is still undiscovered. I also loved the development for both the mum and the dad that happened around mid-way through the book - parental development is also something rare in a YA book.

The setting was nostalgic, beautiful historical fiction in the 90s, and although I've never liked LA as a city I felt like I was transported back to my own senior year of high school. The author's writing style was filled with fluid flashbacks - sometimes scenes were so well-executed I had to stop and put down the book to process it all, or wipe away my tears. The whole second half of the book escalated so well that I couldn't stop reading.

In conclusion, this book is similar to The Hate U Give, but possibly even better. It deals with racial themes, and so much more. It deals with friendship, family, love, feminism, growing up and learning to live with not just injustice, but your reponse to it. And on top of that, it's incredibly well written. I would highly recommend this astonishing debut novel to anyone I know.

Here are a few of my favourite quotes from the book:
"Sometimes when your grown-ups are sad, their sadness feels even heavier than your own."
"Don't you ever get tired of being a symbol? Don't you ever just want to be human?"
"Maybe Jo and I are more alike than not, just broken in different places. I miss my sister in the present tense."
"Sometimes there is an us, sometimes there is a them, and sometimes it's okay to be a we."

Title: Winnie the Pooh: The Best Bear in All the World
Author: A.A. Milne
Additional Authors: Paul Bright, Brian Sibley, Jeanne Willis, Kate Saunders
My Review:
This is probably a five star book for kids, but still holds up as a four star book even for adults. My boyfriend and I had so much fun reading through this nostalgic volume, picking and adjusting our accents - from Tigger's hoo-hoo-hoo-hooooo to Eeyore's gloomy moan - and making beautiful memories as we shared this story together.

It's a nice set of four discrete stories, separated by seasons, and illustrated stunningly to match. We found Jeanne Willis's story about Eeyore being scared there was Another Donkey to be overall the best, with Kate Saunders' hilarious tale about a ravenous Pooh Bear looking for the "Sauce" of the river being easily the funniest. Each of the characters had brilliant little idiosyncracies, which made it easy enough to switch between voices, and the new stories stayed true to the original themes.

We remember first reading about Winnie the Pooh in little Golden Books - but over 15 years later, we're still getting the same kind of joy out of these stories, and I think that's something beautiful in itself.

Title: Throne of Glass (Throne of Glass, #1)
Author: Sarah J. Maas
My Review:
It's very easy to fall into the world of Sarah J Maas's Throne of Glass. Her prose is so beautiful at times it makes my heart happy just reading it. At other times, it feels like her glowing descriptions of clothing and the main character's own beauty are going a bit too far - but simultaneously, that kind of description (and character focus) is something that makes the book different.

Throne of Glass and its main character Celaena are interesting, positive takes on teenage femininity. It's very much what I would call a young women's fantasy. Despite a bunch of cliches - like a love triangle - and a similar plot to The Hunger Games, I really appreciated the way Maas developed her world, most of all. And I look forward to how she will develop her characters beyond the existing predictable plotline. The characters of Kaltain, Nox, and particular Nehemia - and their relationship with Celaena - were a breath of fresh air, and very enjoyable to read about.

Sarah J Maas sets up a very believeable magic system with a believable plot structure - part Hunger Games, part murder mystery, part romance - but most importantly everything came together well. I'm excited to read the next book, because despite all the cliches and tropes I really like this set of characters and I'm interested to see what happens to them next.

Title: Seven Ancient Wonders
Author: Matthew Reilly
My Review:
True to form, Reilly's Seven Ancient Wonders is like reading an Indiana Jones movie - as a novel. Unlike his other books, this one is action-adventure, and there's less straight-up fighting and killing because it's about problem solving, riddles and puzzles. Reilly's action scenes go at breakneck speed when you're reading it, despite his overuse of ellipses (...), exclamation marks (!) and italics. Everything's a little bit over the top, but that's okay when you're watching an action movie and you don't expect much more.

I realise that I learned to write like this, and it's been an interesting exploration of everything I've learnt since I first read Reilly's books at 13. Don't use too many adjectives or adverbs, don't use two words when one will do, and don't! use! too many! exclamation marks! Nonetheless, Reilly's book holds up to some extent - he has a firm grasp on world politics at the time, and interestingly uses the place of Australia for his main hero. He also pulls the interesting trick of making the main characters into a little family. Unfortunately his characters are all a bit two-dimensional, and the only one who leaped off the page for me was Lily - ironically, the person who was doing the least LEAPING in this book.

I'm glad I read this book, particularly to reflect on the way my writing style has grown. Reilly's action scenes are masterful, but his plot and his characters let him down. You've really got to suspend your disbelief for a lot of the "history" in use. It's a bit of a mixed bag, ultimately - but if you're looking to read the equivalent of a fast-paced action movie with bits of Indiana Jones, bits of National Treasure, and bits of The Da Vinci Code, this is it.

Title: Boy Swallows Universe
Author: Trent Dalton
My Review:
I was prepared to not like this book, because I've disliked almost every "great Australian novel" I've ever read, but Dalton's novel was different. It still wasn't my perfect cup of tea, with a storyline that sidelined all its women, and various confusing bits or bits that were actively unpleasant to read, so I've only given it 4 stars, but there are three main reasons this book is worth reading:
1. Somehow it is more relatable and uniquely Australian, more so than any other book I have read. It's set in Brisbane in the 80s, and there are things the characters do at school, or refer to around the city, which are uniquely things that only Brisbanites or Queenslanders generally would know. And somehow, Dalton manages to make it all sound exciting, and make it part of the story, especially with the characters' youth.
2. Dalton has a wonderful writing style, which draws on some Aussie-isms but mostly is just very consistent. Dalton's voice seems weird at first in the head of a 12 year old boy, but as the character ages it all starts to gel very nicely. His detailed but fast writing style is differnet to anything I've read - and it's simultaneously thematic and important to the main character.
3. The plotline and the characters are very well done (except for the female characters, as noted above). It deals with a realistic drug scene (I know, I work in a similar area), deals with themes of family, love, hope and how to get past a life of crime, and it manages to balance some "weird" magical realism with what would otherwise be harsh reality.
It's like an Australian Neil Gaiman novel, whose story is uniquely told and comes together effectively. In the final part of the book, I just couldn't stop reading. In some ways, it was like watching a train crash, but in other ways it was like watching a flower bloom. I had complicated feelings about this book, but I think it was for the best that I did. I'm glad I read Boy Swallows Universe.

Author: Bruce Pascoe
My Review: As far as non fiction books go, this is a good one - it investigates something inherently interesting and inherently important, and it does so with tenacity and authenticity. I admire this book for what it is, but this book is not a comprehensive discussion of the topic - I wanted to be more convinced than I was, and I think that even deeper discussion of the issues surrounding our First Nations agriculture and land ownership will be very valuable for our future as a nation. This book is very important, and it taught me a lot, but it is only scraping the surface. Put simply, I want to know more.

Title: The Poet X
Author: Elizabeth Acevedo
My Review: I'm tempted to say this is the best book I have read in a very long time. I was tearing up by the end of it, with all of the feelings it gave me. And I read it in one afternoon! This is a fast-paced, authentic book in verse - it has memorable characters, excellently described and living in the spaces Acevedo creates with her words. This book is powerful and inspirational and I would read it again in a heartbeat and recommend it to everyone in my life, especially the young people I know. It deals with femininity, feminism, love, sex, passion, LGBTIQ themes, friendship, parents, family, race, and religion somehow altogether, throwing them all into a giant melting pot of raw emotion straight from the heart. This book resonates better than any YA novel I've read in a long time, and Acevedo's use of poetry is perfectly adapted to the story that she tells. I can't wait to read more by this author!

Title: A Wild Sheep Chase
Author: Haruki Murakami
My Review: 3.5 Stars! This book was easy to read but difficult to understand. By the time you get to the end of it, you realise what it was all about, but it doesn't stop you from being generally frustrated about the long way you had to come to get here. Somehow such a short book became such a long adventure, and I know that's the point, but I just felt kind of miffed about being on a wild sheep chase. It was well done (with the lack of names, and with the bringing of the plot together with a hint of magical realism) and I respect it, but it frustrated me to no end.

Title: The Sun Is Also a Star
Author: Nicola Yoon
My Review: This is a brilliant, heartwarming, heartbreaking book - all in one. The characters were really well developed and well rounded, and I wanted to keep reading to find out what happened to these people I'd become so attached to over the course of the book. It deals with racial themes and immigration questions, particularly deportation - a really hard issue for a lot of people. And it doesn't take it lightly. As someone currently working as a paralegal in this area of law in Australia, about to finish my law degree and hoping to become an immigration lawyer, I'm simultaneously appalled and just kind of sad about the US experience of undocumented immigrants. This was a really genuine, unique, but hopeful insight into this situation that affects so many people in our world - it was a story of being torn apart and trying to put yourself back together. It was poetic, and it was done very well. I would highly recommend this to anyone.

Title: A Darkling Plain (The Hungry City Chronicles, #4)
Author: Philip Reeve
My Review: I loved reading this audiobook! The world was so well developed, and the characters great - I just wanted to get back into it constantly. Everything was alive. It was a typical long winded fantasy/sci fi but its many positives made up for it. It gave an interesting comment on ecofascism, as well as incredible concluding observations on the importance of telling stories, the understanding of mortality, and the relevance of stories to history. The ending scene was pure gold. Not to mention the fact that it deals with older characters in a romance, and for a YA book does an impressive amount of considering intergenerational issues. The use of Stalkers as a plot device was unique and interesting, and although this book suffers from some cliches it is altogether one of the best series in this genre I have read.

Title: Exit Strategy (The Murderbot Diaries, #4)
Author: Martha Wells
My Review: This book is brilliant, even better than the other Murderbot books I have read so far. Wells has a very unique way of writing action scenes from inside Murderbot's head and gives Murderbot an extremely memorable voice. I haven't felt any other character was as alive as this one in ages! Plus, as a 4th book, it's really starting to pick up with great character development, and we are thoroughly invested. I would recommend this series very highly to everyone!

Author: Mackenzi Lee

Author: Samantha Shannon

Title: Girl, Woman, Other
Author: Bernardine Evaristo
My Review: This book blew me away. It was a love letter to black women, brown women, womxn in general, and a beautiful exploration of history all in one. It was so deeply thought out and felt, it hit home constantly - over and over again, no matter the age or the tendencies of each character. I've never read a book like this before and I don't know when I ever will again. I'm not one for re-reads, but getting back inside the heads of such well-developed characters, inside such a flowing, poetic prose style from Evaristo, would be nothing but wonderful. I'm sure there would be even more to pick up on a second read! I would 1000% recommend this book - I didn't think I was going to like it, and I was unsure how I'd get through it, but I am super glad I picked it up. Reading it was a breeze! Thank you to Life's Library book club and Tuataria for helping me find this author, and this book - it's one I will remember for a long time yet.

Title: Any Way the Wind Blows (Simon Snow, #3)
Author: Rainbow Rowell

Author: Amal El-Mohtar

Title: The Flight of the Darkstar Dragon
Author: Benedict Patrick

Title: The Theory of Hummingbirds
Author: Michelle Kadarusman
My Review: It's been a long time since I read a middle grade book (since I was actually in middle school I'd say!) but I loved this book nonetheless. It had sweet little messages about friendship and family, and believing in yourself, and was a really nice light read. It was also told very well, with believable characters and great dialogue, and it hinted at a bunch of important adult themes, like divorced/widowed parents finding love again. I really appreciated this book and I think I would have liked it as a kid too!

Title: Blonde Roots
Author: Bernardine Evaristo
My Review: This book for me read like The Handmaid's Tale, and I'm not sure why. It might have been the white main character taking the place of a black main character, or the just plain weird fantasy-ness of it all, but overall it was an interesting, insightful, and bold book. It was a great experience to read, and it made me think! Would recommend for everyone who is realising they need to better understand the experience of Black people and their ancestors in the slave trade.

Author: Christopher Paolini

Author: Bethany C. Morrow

Title: Beloved
Author: Toni Morrison
My Review: The vivid imagery in this book was so intense and powerful, and the writing was so good, it made me feel physically sick or like I wanted to throw up. It wasn't an enjoyable experience by any means, and there were only a few moments of respite throughout the entire book. I listened to the audiobook, so the author's reading voice really helped me understand and make sense of the world, and the surrealist parts. I'm not a fan of horror but this book was full of many of its best tropes, scary things done well. I didn't personally like it very much, but I think its position as a classic is clear and its dealing with themes, especially about slavery, is very commendable. I gained an insight into the lives of Black people in the US Civil War Period that I couldn't have gained any other way. I felt immersed in this book.

Title: All the Crooked Saints
Author: Maggie Stiefvater
My Review: Maggie Steifvater has a beautifully unique writing style that is always a pleasure to read. Her characters are decent and well developed, and she adds an element of self-awareness to each of them, and to the book in general. Stand-alones with a very clear theme like this book are really interesting as literature and definitely some food for thought despite being YA. Beautiful little world, good characters and theme - an enjoyable read.

Title: The Long Way to a Small, Angry Planet (Wayfarers, #1)
Author: Becky Chambers

Title: Rogue Protocol (The Murderbot Diaries, #3)
Author: Martha Wells
My Review: Another fast-paced action story from Murderbot's unique perspective, complete with humour and drama and unsuspecting moments, and good, worthwhile character development! I can't recommend this series enough - it's easy to read, but it's simultaneously thought-provoking and the world is immersive. I can't wait for the next one

Author: Holly Black

Title: Infernal Devices (The Hungry City Chronicles, #3)
Author: Philip Reeve
My Review: I loved the first two books and I think I might just love this one even more. They've added interesting dimensions to every character, added new characters that come right off the page, and developed the plot to a place that's great in the lead up to the final book. It was a bit slow at first, but some of the best fantasy fiction is like that. The inter-generational character set is unique to these books, and they make you feel for their entire history. You're at knife's edge of tension for the entire end quarter of the book, and you don't know what the characters are going to do. Maybe Hester's not going to save the day any more - and then what? This book brings into question everything earlier in the series. As a sequel, particularly a penultimate sequel, it does its job extremely well. I am so excited for the next one!

Title: Moonwalking with Einstein: The Art and Science of Remembering Everything
Author: Joshua Foer

Author: Julia Baird

Title: Phosphorescence: On Awe, Wonder and Things That Sustain You When the World Goes Dark
Author: Julia Baird
My Review: This is a beautiful, thoughtful gem of a book. It isn't preachy but it answers your questions nonetheless. It gives you concrete examples of how to lead a happy life regardless of your situation, regardless of everything going wrong or things looking dark. It's a collection of shorts by a thoughtful, intelligent writer, that can be picked up at any point and read for a reminder of what is important. I would highly recommend this insightful book.

Title: The Inexplicable Logic of My Life
Author: Benjamin Alire Sáenz

Title: Artificial Condition (The Murderbot Diaries, #2)
Author: Martha Wells
My Review: I didn't think this could improve upon the first book, but it really did. There were so many interesting new paths this book went down, so many different things it exploded - gender is dealt with in an interesting way, and there are constantly interesting plots about the politics and reality of the world. It's really an excellently developed world, and there's next to no exposition about it. It's also such a fast, enjoyable read! Brilliant - I can't wait to read more!

My Review: I listened to the new BBC Audiobook version and gosh this was a very entertaining two hours. No matter whether you are young or old, this book is something special - it's simulatenously lighthearted and deals with complicated themes, and it's a brilliant example of children's literature. It perfectly sets up the more-famous The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, and it's more than just a prequel - it has a very well developed plot and hints at significant character development in the future. Would highly recommend. It doesn't really have enough substance to warrant 5 stars, but it's about as brilliant as it could possibly be otherwise.

It's an interesting world and I'm hoping the next book will develop it further. Would recommend for anyone searching for a very readable sci fi / postapocalyptic book to fill their time.

Author: Jess  Hill

Title: Sophie's World
Author: Jostein Gaarder
My Review: This is an extremely unique and thoughtful book, which will stay with you for a long time. It explores the history of philosophy and is very enlightening and easy to understand. Better yet, it's more than that - it's a book where the characters literally start trying to leap off the pages! Would highly recommend it to anyone, especially people interested in philosophy and not knowing where to start.

Title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (Extraordinary Voyages, #3)
Author: Jules Verne
My Review: Even though this book has aged over time, it remains timeless with its great characters and fast-paced, uniquely scientific and well-thought-out plot. It's a compelling read and I would absolutely recommend it.

My Review: This is an extremely underrated and very interesting YA novel, with well developed themes and well developed characters. I was surprised initially that it was so compelling, and I am very glad I randomly chose to read this book. Its premise is constantly compelling, even if you read it over a long time as an audiobook like I did. Would highly recommend!

My Review: Incredibly well illustrated, and solid story being told, but definitely the start of a bigger series. Villain is a bit of a caricature but I'm looking forward to seeing them do something more with these characters.

I would definitely recommend it, especially for anyone who is interested in understanding and empathizing more with people with physical disabilities like cerebral palsy. The twist at the end was devastating and I rushed to finish this book. Brilliant writing.

Title: The Knife of Never Letting Go (Chaos Walking, #1)
Author: Patrick Ness
My Review: Although the weird writing style of this book and the accent of the main character are deeply annoying (especially in audiobook version) it's a very fast book and is best read in a paper copy. The villains are compelling and so are the main characters, just mysterious enough to keep you interested, and the overarching theme is very interesting. It resolves itself nicely despite ending on a cliffhanger. Definitely a good one to read for YA fiction.

Title: Aristotle and Dante Discover the Secrets of the Universe (Aristotle and Dante Discover the Secrets of the Universe, #1)
Author: Benjamin Alire Sáenz

My Review: Incredible audiobook, read by Lin Manuel Miranda with charisma and talent. Also generally a fantastic book, written very well and well plotted. Every chapter kept me enthralled. Would highly recommend.

It was just particularly engaging, with Eddie Redmayne's voice, and with JK Rowling's incredibly inclusive way of writing - making you feel like the Wizarding World truly is real. It's so well written, and after so many years I'm finding myself back loving the magic of Harry Potter.

My Review: Read a fantastic audiobook version on Spotify! This is a really well written book - would highly recommend.

Title: The Hate U Give

My Review: This book had a very powerful message but for me a lot of its power was tempered by how teenage its other themes were. But the characters are very well characterised, unique among books of this genre, and it was written in a very conversational easy-to-read style.

Author: Tom  Jones

Title: On the Road
Author: Jack Kerouac
My Review: Overall there's a reason this book is a classic - it's a very interesting read, with a very unique style. It's confusing, not well edited/well-styled/easy-to-read, but that's almost part of its charm.

Title: Sputnik Sweetheart
Author: Haruki Murakami
My Review: I absolutely raced through this book - it was a thrilling experience to read, and riddled through with incredible literary devices. Its theme is wonderful and leaves you satisfied, though at the same time it keeps you wondering and keeps you wondering for the whole course of the book. I would highly recommend this to anyone.

Title: Eggshell Skull
Author: Bri Lee
My Review: As a law student who is concerned about social justice, this book was underwhelming. As a writer interested in a good story, this book was great. I'm divided in my opinion about it mostly because although it is insightful, it delivers a very one-sided opinion on a particular issue - in a way that twists people's understanding of how the system works. It's an insightful book generally but I'm not convinced it's a great representation of how the law in Brisbane works.

Title: Beneath the Wheel
Author: Hermann Hesse
My Review: I read this book way too slowly but it's a very interesting and classic description of how too much pressure to perform can impact on the mental health of young people. I think it needs to be read more frequently in the modern day - it is deeply applicable.

Author: Gabbie Stroud

Author: Cassandra Clare

Author: Duncan J. Watts
My Review: Not really all that engaging, but one of the first non fiction books I've got through in a while. It gives some interesting insights, but ultimately it's a bit old and too much work in reading through it for the little gain in knowledge it provides.

Title: The Handmaid's Tale (The Handmaid's Tale, #1)
Author: Margaret Atwood
My Review: Absolutely loved this book - even better than the TV series. Atwood is incredible at getting inside your head with the way her protagonist talks, and the themes in the story are endlessly interesting while the pace of the story never suffers. All in all a fantastic read, and recommended for all who want to see an equal world as we know it and understand where the weaknesses in our society lie.

Title: The Concept of Law (Clarendon Law Series)
Author: H.L.A. Hart
My Review: Definitely the best read in my course on Jurisprudence - it was quite readable and very much a great read for a law student hoping to understand the legal system on a conceptual level.

Title: How Musicals Work: And How To Write Your Own
Author: Julian Woolford

Title: Lord of Shadows (The Dark Artifices, #2)
Author: Cassandra Clare
My Review: You'd think Clare's plot structure would be getting predictable by now, but the biggest beats and the finale are absolutely stunning. The characters feel alive, and loveable, and unique - every last one of them. It's the kind of book where you can't help but feel lonely when you close it on the last page. Clare is a master in her genre and I look forward to more of her books.

Title: Turtles All the Way Down
Author: John Green
My Review: If there's one YA book you need to read this year, this is it. John Green's characters are well developed and interesting, and the book leaves you with a profound understanding of mental illness and what it really is. It's difficult to put into words, but John has done it. This book is his best yet, and it will stay with me for a long time.

Title: Promise Me, Dad: A Year of Hope, Hardship, and Purpose
Author: Joe Biden

Title: Batwoman, Volume 1: Hydrology
Author: J.H. Williams III
Additional Authors: W. Haden Blackman, Amy Reeder, Richard Friend
My Review: The defining feature of this book is the masculinity and uniqueness of the main character. She's not particularly likeable, and she's drawn in a very action-based manner, making her just like any old male superhero in a comic book. Batwoman is compelling and her backstory is interesting, so I'm intrigued and want to learn more. The book is quite graphic in terms of violence/gore, and vaguely risque, so it's not everyone's cup of tea, but it's very impressive and progressive for the first book about a lesbian superhero that I've read.

Title: The Letters of Abélard and Héloïse
Author: Pierre Abélard
Additional Authors: Héloïse d'Argenteuil, Betty Radice, M.T. Clanchy

Title: Ms. Marvel, Vol. 1: No Normal
Author: G. Willow Wilson
My Review: I love how progressive this book is. It's a very typical superhero tale with little complexity to the plot, but it's really enjoyable to read about a young Muslim woman who has to deal with the same problems as everyone else her age. It has so much potential - I can't wait to read more about her!

Title: Pachinko
Author: Min Jin Lee
My Review: I loved this book. It's intellectual and makes a point, but at the same time it's easy to read. Lee's omniscient style is perfect for this kind of historical drama, and she includes the perfect number of small details that keep the scenes vivid in your mind. At the same time, she's also focused on the big picture and changed the way I think about families and honour and sacrifice. Good books should give you a glimpse into the mind of the characters inside them, and steal you away from your own life, and Min Jin Lee has done just that.

Title: Wonder Woman, Volume 6: Bones
Author: Brian Azzarello
My Review: I love this comic book series and I'm not a comic book reader. After I was spellbound by the recent Wonder Woman movie, this comic was fantastic to read. I'd never liked Wonder Woman before but I think the new depth she's been given is fantastic, and outstanding for feminism and being a role model for little girls everywhere. She demonstrates that you can be big and strong AND beautiful, AND true to yourself, all while keeping up a pretty solid sense of humour. It's pretty fantastic, and so is the plotline. Unfortunately I've just been reading whatever episode my local library has on the shelves, so it's been entirely out of order, but it's still an interesting plot regardless.

Title: Wonder Woman, Volume 1: Blood
Author: Brian Azzarello

Author: Stephanie Dray

Title: Are You My Mother?
Author: Alison Bechdel
My Review: Bechdel's second graphic novel is an insightful and thoughtful read, a quick read, and is very unique in the way it utilises psychological theory. However, this gives it a tendency to become obscure and confusing, as in this book it often does. Overall, this book is not as good as Fun Home, but is still a worthwhile read.

Title: Wonder Woman, Volume 2: Guts
Author: Brian Azzarello

My Review: Generally good plotline, if a little predictable, but a very easy and exciting read. I loved the way Wonder Woman is characterised, fantastically a hero for a new generation of women. This is my first time reading a comic and I am pleasantly surprised.

Title: Vinland Saga, Volume 1: For Honor and Vengeance

Title: Confessions of an Ugly Stepsister
Author: Gregory Maguire
My Review: This book was very slow, and only redeemed itself somewhat at the end when everything came together. Maguire's ideas are fantastic and original, and his plot is decent, but his general writing style is easily quite boring.

Title: Carry On
Author: Rainbow Rowell
My Review: For a teenage book, and a clear Harry Potter parody, this was an awesome book. The main romance was very well planned and executed, and the plot was surprising even for readers of Harry Potter. The characters were all loveable and well developed, and there were several laugh-out-loud moments. It was a nice easy read too, and I'd skim through it again in a heartbeat.

Title: The Secret Agent
Author: Joseph Conrad
My Review: This book is really gripping for a "classic". it reads generally like a police procedural in the middle, and is interesting in its description of the Verlocs at the beginning, but otherwise unmemorable until the last few chapters with Mrs Verloc. Those scenes are worth it in the end - they are amazingly written and keep you in the mind of characters, and provide compelling reasons to follow the characters through a very stressful climax to the novel.

Title: The Winds of Winter (A Song of Ice and Fire, #6)
Author: George R.R. Martin

Title: Love in a Bottle and Other Stories
Author: Antal Szerb
My Review: A well written set of interesting short stories, with inbuilt themes that leave the reader with a sense of satisfaction long after the story is finished - characters are well developed, plots are excellently orchestrated, and the morals are clear. This is masterful short story work, and much easier to read than most "classics". I really liked it :)

Title: A Distant Mirror:  The Calamitous 14th Century
Author: Barbara W. Tuchman

Title: The Lies of Locke Lamora (Gentleman Bastard, #1)
Author: Scott Lynch

Title: The Raven King (The Raven Cycle, #4)
Author: Maggie Stiefvater
My Review: This book is incredibly well-constructed, the vocab choice pulls at your head and your heart,  and the characters are brilliantly made - they feel like real people and, when the book ends, you're just sad it's over. The plot was both ambitious and satisfying, and it was all in all a very enjoyable read. In my current state of shock, that's just about all I can say.

Title: Caligula (The Lives of the Twelve Caesars #4)
Author: Suetonius

Title: The Fall of the House of Usher and Other Stories
Author: Edgar Allan Poe

Title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1)
Author: J.K. Rowling

Title: The Secret River
Author: Kate Grenville
My Review: Generally, this book has way too much unnecessary description, and the plot only gets interesting in the last sixth of the book. It's a lot of work slaving through pages of Australian landscape, but in the end it's worth reading because it paints a comprehensive and (sometimes metaphorical) picture of the actual situation with indigenous people in Australia. It's very well researched and makes a great point at the end of the story. My favourite part was the depiction of the story from both angles - the white settlers/convicts aren't necessarily painted purely as villains but given some sympathy. Possibly the sympathy is a little too strong, but Grenville makes it clear that the end situation is far from perfect and gives us an uneasy feeling about the mistreatment of indigenous people in Australia. All in all, it wasn't entertaining, but it was a nevertheless well-researched read with an admirable ending.
